I interviewed at NVIDIA in 1/2/2025

In total I had three Interviews at Nvidia, a standard process. First technical Interview with a senior and a group manager. They describe the job and process in detail, and were very positive. It was not 100% what I looked for but the Manager called me afterwards to say I'm a a good candidate etc and exactly what he is looking for and I got a good vibe so I continued. The Second Interview, called technical. However was not asked any coding questions or any hands on question... very weird., and quite low quality Third with HR. I was called to the next interview soon after finishing So I was surprised I didn't get an offer right away, since I answered all the questions. Reason being - they got the impression that I gave the impression that Im not looking for a hands on position. Which felt kind of unfair I also had a struggle with their way of counting experience. Overall, to get in just say you want to work there and code and be OK with whatever the terms.
Are your comfortable with coding

Total of 5 round, 1 screening round consist of coding and OS question, 4 techs round consist of coding, OS, design, architecture, cultural fit. They are also interested in how deep your knowledge is in fundamentals

The process took 2 weeks.I interviewed at NVIDIA (Sunnyvale, CA) in 12/5/2024

The interviewer was poorly communicative and seemed inexperienced. She didn’t turn on her camera, even though I had mine on during the online interview. She initially asked me to explain the architecture of a project. After I provided, she said it wasn’t what she wanted. When she struggled to express herself, she became impatient and spoke in a rushed manner. As a software engineer who has successfully passed technical interviews with offers from FAANG companies, I expected a more professional experience. Unfortunately, my interviewer at NVIDIA did not seem to have sufficient coding experience. The problem she presented was straightforward, and I solved it using a two-pointer approach in just four lines of code. She claimed she didn’t understand what I was trying to do. I provided three different solutions, but it seemed she had a specific method in mind, which she never say it. The solution she might have wanted wasn’t more tome-efficient, just different. When I attempted to engage in a discussion, there were silences, leading me to repeatedly ask if the connection was still active. Despite my solution being correct, passing all test cases, and with plenty of time remaining in the interview, she ended it early and informed me the same day that I had not passed.
Project technical questions. Easy coding question.

NVIDIA's interview is known to be rigorous and technical, reflecting its focus on innovation in GPUs, AI, and other cutting-edge technologies. Online Coding Tests: Some positions may require you to complete a coding or technical assessment. Platforms like HackerRank or NVIDIA's internal tools might be used. The test often includes: Algorithms and data structures. Problem-solving challenges. Role-specific questions, such as CUDA programming for GPU-related roles or system design for hardware-focused roles.
Most Algorithms and Data Structure leetcode type of questions

The first round on HackerRank comprises 40 questions covering aptitude, operating systems, general AI, data structures, software testing, SQL, and machine learning. Successful candidates proceed to a technical interview via Microsoft Teams, focusing on problem-solving and coding. Finally, a managerial interview assesses leadership, teamwork, and alignment with organizational goals.

I applied through an employee referral. I interviewed at NVIDIA in 12/28/2024

I came across the job posting on the company's website. After submitting my resume through a friend who works there, I received a call from the company's recruiter. She scheduled a phone interview with the team manager for about half an hour. During that call, the manager provided an overview of the role and asked about my previous work experience. The next day, I was invited to a 1.5-hour virtual interview with the hiring manager and another employee from the company. During this interview, I was asked both technical questions and questions related to my teamwork and problem-solving abilities.

Tell me about a project you worked on. Tell me about the architecture of something you are responsible for in your current job. Why do you want to leave your current job? Technical Questions: One question was a relatively easy LeetCode problem. The second question was to write as many functions as possible that take an 'X' or 'Y' as input and return the opposite. The third question was to write an API.

I applied online. The process took 3 days.I interviewed at NVIDIA in 11/22/2024

1. First round was screening round and then 3 rounds were scheduled in 2 days once screening round was cleared. It was mentioned first round was on AUTOSAR & functional safety, second round on C programming and third round on soft skills. But interviewers did not stick to this at all, all the interviewers asked everything. On the last round, instead of soft skills, he asked me on few OS concepts. I had mentioned that I have worked on OS topics in AUTOSAR for few months and I had a vast area of expertise other than OS. But interviewer had only worked on OS and did not know anything else. So he was expecting me to have gone through stack implementation and check the code till register level. First thing is that that’s too much expectation on someone who has worked on it only for few months compared to him who worked on only that for more than a decade, second thing is he was so arrogant and was not letting me explain anything. Arrogance was due to the fact that he is in NVIDIA, which was not at all expected. That’s so sad to see something like happening in NVIDIA. I think he did not select me because of his ego issues and arrogance. Anyway, I attended 4 technical rounds after which I did not get any response from HR too. HR people does not have basic common sense to intimate candidate that they have or they haven’t been selected, which is again so sad to see in such a big company too. One thing for sure, is that they look for strong fundamentals and ask basic questions.
1. Where is memory allocated for local const, global const, local static const, global static const 2. Write a derived datatype to access 1 register byte or each bit in that register separately

I'm writing a negative review for Glassdoor for the first time, and I'm doing it to ensure that what I experienced in the interview doesn’t happen to other candidates. I interviewed for the HRBP position at the Israeli site. I have 11 years of experience, having worked at some of the best and most recognized companies, and I've gone through numerous job interviews throughout my career. Some experiences were positive, while others were less so, but I always thanked the interviewers and moved on—until this interview. My candidate experience was the worst I can describe, even traumatic. I was interviewed by two interviewers, one junior and one senior. They introduced themselves pleasantly at the beginning of the interview, and then it began: they interrupted me rudely almost every word I said, made faces, mocked, belittled, and dismissed me. Furthermore, the questions were irrelevant and unprofessional. Typically, interview questions follow a format like: "Tell me about a situation where X occurred, what was the situation? What did you do?" In this case, the interviewers presented a current situation and asked what I would do, but provided no context. I would elaborate more on what happened in the interview and how serious it was, but the page is too short to contain it. This was the first time I almost stopped an interview midway. I still haven’t received a response from them. The answer will likely be negative, but even if it’s not, there’s no chance I would want to work at a place represented by those individuals! I wish the interview had been recorded so it could be shared as a lesson on how not to conduct interviews. I’ve been interviewing for years myself. Even when a candidate seems like a poor fit, I try to give them a pleasant experience. I would never rudely interrupt, belittle, or do the things I experienced in this interview. I’ve heard such great things about the company, and I’m so disappointed now. What a shame.
We currently have a situations that 2 teams are not working together smoothly and there is a lake of communication. The HR and VP of one of the teams is not collaborating with you. What would you do?

On-campus hiring for NCG in IISc Bengaluru. 1. Online test: No of questions: 19 Time: 50 mins Difficulty level: Moderate to hard. Topics covered: COA, Digital electronics, aptitude. Questions were lengthy to read and process but quickly solvable once understood. 2. Technical interview: Panel of 2-3. Duration: 1 hour Questions from online test that you were unable to solve. Technical questions from COA, logic design, digital VLSI etc. Puzzles to test your thinking. Discussion regarding projects mentioned in your resume. 3. HR interview: 10 min discussion round to assess your behavior and personality.
Gave me a digital circuit and asked me to identify and explain it's functionality first. Then write the verilog code for it.

I applied online. The process took 2 months.I interviewed at NVIDIA (Santa Clara, CA) in 10/24/2024

The process took around 2 months, in which I had 2 interviews via teams over the span of two months, one with a project member and one with the project lead. Basic questions about my resume and fundamental architecture questions were asked. After that was the panel round where I interviewed with four of the team members. The first panel interview went well though when doing the technical question by hand, I messed up a lot, but still got the right answer. The second team member did not ask me many "technical" questions but mostly stuff on my resume, but asked me stuff I didn't work on. It felt weird when I said I did x,y,z that they asked me something tangential, that my impression from the rest of my interviews, they didn't even seem to care about. I said something correct, but with the wrong reasoning to that, but overall the rest of the technical questions I answered fine that had to do with my experience. Third interview was a complete mess. The interviewer did not define any of the problems completely. Imagine being asked to do the operation "whats 5 and 6?" multiple times and asking for clarification and getting "whats 5 and 6 together?" and having to guess each time whether its 11 or 30. I should've known this when I referenced a common operation in PyTorch/NumPy/Tensorflow, and he seemed to be clueless about the notation. Final interview was great but fundamentally had the same problems as all the other interviews. They asked me do I know "tensor parallelism" which my immediate response in my head is "what a dumb name, you fundamentally have three tensors, an input, output and weight tensor, and only one of them is parallel." While I felt this was my strongest interview because at this point since I was more used to asking for definitions and taking shots if they refused define them. This interview also featured the work I was most closely working on the past two years, but it still felt like there was a bit of pulling teeth when talking to them. I have been working on these problems for a long time in the accelerator space, and thought even though this job was GPU based I'd be fine. The accelerator space seems to clearly define these terms better by talking about them in terms of stuff like "fine-grained parallelism" or "coarse-grained parallelism" (see tangram out of Stanford) referring to how close to the compute they are or "weight stationary," "output stationary," "input stationary," or "row stationary" (see work by Joel Emer and Vivienne Sze) to define which part of the tensor is the one moving (though that's just the primary one, as secondary ones don't have a defined order, but there are notations to talk about complete movement) and additional work even has high level languages or representations to define these movements (see Maestro out of GATech). Coming from that space into this, feels like speaking a completely different language where every word sounds the same and has no reflection on their meaning. To be completely clear, I am willing to learn all these translations, words, or definitions, but asking to do this on the spot without preparation to me reads as insane. It feels bad that constantly throughout the panel I had to fight with translating loosely defined words, or ill-conceived problems that in order to answer, I'd have to fundamentally be completely reactive to. I don't believe any role would actually have me do this, that it would be sit down and understand the stuff before simulating it, but within this process all I was given was a mix of poorly formulated problems and definitions that only makes sense to the people asking it a lot of the time. I don't believe they actually tested my ability to do the job, and at best they tested if I'd be as good as them day 1 which seems unreasonable. I'd find it hard pressed for anyone to pass the same process I went through without additional information about the language, types of problems being asked, them more clearly defining problems, or some form of nepotism.
How to analyze deep learning primitives.

I applied online. The process took 4 weeks.I interviewed at NVIDIA in 10/17/2024

First interview was great, hiring manager was friendly and went over my resume politely and in reasonable depth. Second round was two hour long interviews with 3 to 4 members of the team. Incredibly rude people off the bat, nothing I said was received positively even when I gave the answer they were looking for. Asked me to troubleshoot a theoretical situation but would give no feedback on anything that would influence my troubleshooting, just kept repeating that it was a theoretical situation. Couldn't even bother to listen to me so when they asked a question and I replied, they'd paraphrase back what I said but incredibly wrong. If I tried to correct them they insisted that I was wrong (ie interviewer insisted that a local machine a user was connecting from, and a vm the user was connecting to, was the same thing). Shut down the interview saying they "had everything they needed", then took 8 business days to tell me to kick rocks. 0/10 would not interview for another position with this team, clear they have heavy bias against any external applicants and an even heavier need to feel superior. Shame because the company perks seem great.
If someone is reporting lag on the vm, how would you troubleshoot it?

Applied online and was scheduled for an interview a couple of weeks later. The first interview was a technical one with 30 minutes for hackerrank Python coding and 30 minutes for technical questions about skills and projects on my resume. Overall the interviewers were very patient and accommodating. It was generally a chill and positive experience. Time was short and a bit rushed so there was little time for me to go into depth on projects. Very important to remember STAR so as to not ramble about projects. Also very important to explicitly state the technical work you did (be a little egotistical). In my current role, it is taboo to talk about your work using "I" statements, and thus are forced to use "we" to promote a teamwork mentality, even if you've done all the work by yourself. I think this is somewhat common, so just remember to drop that idea and really sell YOU.
Practical Python function question, not really leetcode.

Position: Quality & Performance Testing Engineer. I was selected by an NVIDIA employee for the interview process, where I passed the initial screening and then moved on to the second technical stage. After reviewing the requirements, I realized that I fully met them. The interview was initially planned to include four participants, but none of them were QA specialists. We had agreed on a convenient date and time for the interview, but a few days later, the HR coordinator asked to reschedule due to the absence of one of the participants. We rescheduled the interview, and two days before the new date, I received confirmation. However, on the day of the interview, it was postponed again for the same reason—the same participant was still unavailable. I found this odd: a large company like NVIDIA was unable to demonstrate flexibility and responsibility in organizing an interview that had been scheduled across different time zones. At that point, I asked if it was possible to proceed with the interview with three participants instead of four. The HR had already canceled the meeting but then reconsidered and asked to continue at the scheduled time. The interview itself lasted two hours. For about an hour, I detailed my experience, explaining what I had done and how. During that time, I didn’t receive a single question about the position. There was one technical question and an assignment to fix code generated by artificial intelligence. However, when they asked me to fix the code immediately, I declined, explaining that I could complete the task, but I would need more time. The developer insisted that using anti-patterns, which essentially turn the testing pyramid upside down by relying on minimal and even unnecessary unit test coverage, was normal practice and tried to convince me of this. In the end, I got the impression that they were looking for a DevOps + developer engineer who would also take on QA tasks but with a QA salary. By the way salary range was not mentioned and asked at all. Regardless, it was a useful experience. The next day, I received an offer from another company where the interview process was exactly aligned with my role. I can not say whether interview was difficult or easy. I can say it was not coincide with the role which described in vacancy requirements and responsibilities.

I recently interviewed for a 6-month fixed-term contract as an EMEA Payroll Specialist at Nvidia, and the experience was quite disappointing. The interview process spanned nearly three weeks, with the first interview on June 11 and the final stage on July 1. The final interview was particularly frustrating. It was scheduled at 8 PM UK time to accommodate the newly appointed payroll director in the USA. During the interview, the Director asked very broad and hypothetical questions, none of which pertained to my actual experience or qualifications. It felt like a complete waste of time, as there was no effort to understand my background or skills relevant to the role. To make matters worse, he had mentioned they would get back to me within a week with their decision. It's now been several weeks, and I have received no update whatsoever. This lack of communication is highly unprofessional, especially for a company as large and reputed as Nvidia. Additionally, they emphasized the urgency of filling this position, yet the entire process dragged on for far too long. This contradicts their claim of needing someone urgently. It also became apparent that their payroll process is surprisingly manual and reliant on spreadsheets, despite having Workday as their HCM. This lack of investment and care for payroll operations is shocking for a company of Nvidia's size. In my situation, I had recently been made redundant and was actively seeking employment. Fortunately, I was able to secure another more senior job, but had I waited for Nvidia's response that never came, I would have faced significant financial stress. Their failure to communicate could have had serious consequences for my livelihood, which is unacceptable. Overall, this was a disappointing and unprofessional experience, and it significantly lowered my perception of Nvidia as an employer.
Can you give an example of when you were involved in improving the payroll process?

I applied online. The process took 4 weeks.I interviewed at NVIDIA (Tel Aviv-Yafo) in 8/30/2024

The interview started with simple technical questions where it moved to a stage of questions about personality and teamwork, after some logical content questions and basic questions in programming and logic of operations. A question on the architecture of a basic computer

Concise Explanation and Question In verification, we build test environments to ensure that hardware will function correctly after production. One common testing tool is the PRBS (Pseudo Random Binary Sequence) mechanism, which generates a predetermined bit sequence that simulates real communication. This mechanism allows the receiver to verify the correctness of the received bits based on previous bits without needing additional information from the transmitter, thus saving valuable resources on the chip. Question: Design a digital circuit that implements the following formula with an initial value of 2: X new = X [ 7 ] ⊕ X [ 6 ] X new​=X[7]⊕X[6] Next, design a test circuit that outputs two indications: prbs_ok: An output that will be 1 when the next bit matches the expected one, and 0 otherwise. Counter (counter): Increments by one each time an error in bit detection is identified.

I applied online. I interviewed at NVIDIA in 5/15/2024

First they presented a little presentation about the job and company. Then asked about my resume, grades, courses I took etc. Then went into the actual interview. The interviewer said that the interview would be theoretical but it wasn’t. They gave me two questions, each one we discussed deeply. I still don’t have an answer regarding the next interview but I don’t think I’ll get it. I was not on top of my game because of one course I took three years ago and also because I was told that the interview is theoretical, which it wasn’t. The interviewer insisted I get interviewed very soon even though I communicated that I have finals and that I need to refresh my knowledge of the course I took three years ago. Bad idea. I did not like the interviewer; he was pushy, and too strict. Also his questions were designed to trick which just took away my passion of working for them. For example, I would answer correctly at the first time and he wouldn’t tell me, but ask questions in a “are you sure?” manner. I also could explain with another physical and valid explanation but he would want very specific explanation in his mind (sometimes you can tackle a question more physically in different ways, or mathematically, etc). So that mostly what made the interview difficult. I do not think I’ll get a second interview but even if I did, I’m not sure I want this guy to be my boss, it doesn’t sound promising.
Capacitance Question in Electrostatics, and Charge Distribution

I applied through other source. The process took 3 months.I interviewed at NVIDIA in 6/10/2024

I recently interviewed with NVIDIA, and I wanted to share my experience, which spanned close to three months. Here are some key points regarding my journey: Pros: 1. Excellent Interview Panel: - The interview panel was highly knowledgeable and professional. - The questions were challenging, particularly around LLMs and the generative AI landscape, which made for a stimulating and engaging discussion. - The panelists were thorough in their evaluation and made the interview process intellectually rewarding. 2. Positive Initial Feedback: - I received positive feedback after completing all the interview rounds. - The initial discussions about the offer were encouraging, making me excited about the opportunity at NVIDIA. Cons: 1. Lengthy and Non-Transparent Offer Process: - The offer approval process took over a month, during which communication was sparse. - Despite receiving an initial verbal offer and detailed breakdown of the compensation package, the formal offer was never released on the promised day. - Eventually, I was informed that the position was put on a hiring freeze, which was extremely disappointing. 2. Impact on Other Opportunities: - Due to the extended process and optimistic feedback from NVIDIA, I placed other potential job opportunities on hold or declined them, which in hindsight, was detrimental to my job search. 3. Lack of Transparency: - The HR process lacked transparency and left me in the dark for long periods. - The abrupt announcement of a hiring freeze after an extended waiting period was particularly frustrating and disheartening.

1. In your experience, what are the advantages and disadvantages of fine-tuning a model compared to using the RAG approach? How do you see these methods complementing each other in natural language processing tasks? 2. Can you elaborate on the various techniques available for adapting a foundational LLM to handle domain-specific proprietary data? How do these methods differ in terms of efficacy and practical implementation?

I interviewed at NVIDIA (Hong Kong) in 3/3/2024

Arranged the interview at either early morning or late evening for candidate cuz the interviewer was in different timezones, which affect the interviwee performance. The interviewer mentioned that it is a R&D role, however he/she mentioned that there is no research position in APAC. Does he/she find the contradiction? The interviewer's question are not about past experience in R&D as well as project, which show that he/she doesn't not know how to interview senior rank. His/Her questions are revolving around junior grade / fresh graduate question, and he/she even asked whether you have read the JD. It is your responsibility to clarify the JD as solution architect as the function may vary from company to company. In somecase, JD is not reliable at all. The interview was a mixed feeling. In this region, if you do not have a PhD,better avoid to try, even you have a strong R&D experience.
Did you read the JD?

I applied online. I interviewed at NVIDIA in 5/26/2024

The interview process consisted of 4 interviews + additional chat about company's culture with representative of in-company community. From the very first interview it was kinda clear to me that they think I am a fit so the interviews weren't much of a stress. The whole process took about month and a half (1 interview every week for a month and then waiting for feedback). The communication was very clear and direct, I felt taken care of and informed. As you are being recruited, you are getting assigned a recruitment buddy which set appointments with hiring managers and recruiters. Nvidia is very flexible and will do everything they can to make the process a comfortable experience.
How did [deal with the thing that is related to your position/was listed in required experience]? What was the outcome? (a few variants of that Q)

I had a phone interview of about 40 minutes in which I told about myself, about the courses I have studied so far in my degree and about various projects I have done or currently doing. After that, I had a technical zoom interview, in which I was required to answer various architecture questions regarding a project iv'e done and in addition a live coding leetcode question. The question was not difficult, but I had to explain and talk during all my attempts to solve it, that was the more complex part.

So, basically I was shortlisted through On campus . They first conducted the shortlisting through CGPA . Then the OA was conducted which consisted questions related to aptitude , DBMS, OS and 2 coding questions ,one in C++ and the other one in C. I was selected for interview process along with 30 others.

The panel consisted of 3 persons. They asked me to introduce myself and we discussed projects, which lasted about 20 minutes . then the question related to Operating Systems and 2 coding questions on LinkedList and arrays .which were LeetCode medium level. Then they asked various questions about OOPs , relate to class , object , polymorphism ,inheritance, abstraction , access modifiers , virtual , friend , static keyword. The difference between class and structure , Enum and constant .Then the interviewer asked me if I had some queries.

The interview process consisted of an informational interview followed by three rounds of technical interviews. All interviews were conducted with members of the team that was hiring. The first interview was a conversation about my career goals and interests, as well as the team environment and culture at NVIDIA. This was a "non-evaluative" interview. The three technical interviews covered behavioural questions, like "what are your thoughts on NVIDIA's business model and positioning within the industry", as well as several structured case questions, such as "You're a PM at LinkedIn who has been charged with developing the first mobile version of the app. Walk us through that process."
Tell us about a product you brought to market. How did you plan, manage, and execute that process?

I applied through a recruiter. I interviewed at NVIDIA in 1/31/2024

Initial 2 hr technical/background call with hiring manager, if pass then another 2 phone calls with members of team, if pass then take home assignment to be be presented to panel. Final round used to be on site but now virtual. You don't need to know CUDA programming going in (though experience with OpenMP, CUDA, etc will give you edge) but it seems like they want someone who is familiar with optimizing code using parallel programming and has a decent grasp of GPU architecture and function. A basic knowledge of latency and bandwidth topics was assumed. Not a silly Leetcode style interview...you really have to understand software and hardware interactions and how to optimize common computations done in ML/DL using parallel design. Plenty of follow-up qs will be asked to test understanding.

Questions on how to optimize common deep learning operations on software side, general ML question, brain teaser, explaining how experience relates to parallel computing, and *several* questions on CPU and GPU architecture and how it ties into data management or performance. This was not a leetcode type interview -- you had to understand hardware and software interactions!

The initial stage involves an online HackerRank test, spanning two hours. I was notified that I was being selected for an interview for "Software Engineer Intern". I gave my availability and asked, "what team and/or what role it would be for any information that you have at all would be very helpful". I asked this because there are a wide range of different teams that hiring from that application. The recruiter said they have no idea and could give me zero specific information on the role, "just ask about the role and where you fit in" is what she said. This happened to me 3 times for 2 different intern roles. The team ended up being embedded/system software for the AV driverworks team. So I went into the interviews completely blind and unprepared. Everytime it went varying levels of bad. Where if I was able to just have some minor prep info I would have done immeasurably better. It was a very disappointing experience and I think if I get contacted for another role at Nvidia I will likely decline as I have other opportunities at the same level.
Have you ever written a driver and what was it.

Vou te explicar um roteiro básico que pode ajudar a conduzir entrevistas de forma eficaz. Lembre-se de que esse roteiro pode variar de acordo com a empresa e a posição, mas aqui estão os passos essenciais: lidou com eles. Explore competências técnicas e comportamentais.
qual seu objetivo na empresa

Total 6 rounds, starting with the hiring manager. 3 rounds by folks working in Bangalore and 3 by folks from USA. Half of them asked to describe my industry experience so far, it became a little painful to say the same things 3 times. The hiring manager asked a couple of simple basic questions to ascertain I have not forgotten my basics. As the position was of manager, I was asked some typical people management related questions. All the 6 folks in the interview panel were very friendly and nice people to talk to and made me very comfortable during the whole interview process. What went against me in the final decision, in my opinion, was my lack of people management experience.
How will you tackle an employee who is not meeting your performance expectations ?

I applied online. The process took 5 months.I interviewed at NVIDIA in 3/7/2024

After applying, it took about 2 months to hear anything. I had a short call with the recruiter, followed by a technical screen with another person of the same position. I flew threw this and had a great conversation with the engineer. I was then scheduled for a virtual onsite. Three technical interviews (HTML/CSS, JavaScript, React) followed by an interview with the manager. Flew through the first 2 interviews, the third one moved slower because they had just started using HackerRank which would cause the page to freeze up every time you opened developer tools (which was essential for the exercise). I still completed the functionality with time to spare. Each of the technical calls included 2 engineers, and this third one had a new grad engineer who seemed to be shadowing, but at the end of the call he was the one asking me questions instead of the senior engineers. A bit unusual considering the level of this position. The manager interview wasn't an interview at all, and seemed to just be a call for me to ask questions. I felt I did well and had great feedback during the interviews. They never followed up after I completed these interviews, and it wasn't until almost 2 months later that they sent a rejection email.
Technical Screen I'd consider these LC easy, very simple and at the end they just asked how I'd improve the code.

I applied online. The process took 2 months.I interviewed at NVIDIA (Santa Clara, CA) in 3/26/2024

Got an email hearing back after about 3 months since I applied. They told me which team was interested in my resume. Scheduled a 30 minute behavioral interview with the director of the engineering team. They told me about the team, what they do, and asked questions about things on my resume. Although the Ignite program is described as a pre-internship for underrepresented students from low resources, it seemed like the interviewer wasn't aware of that, never asked why I was interested in the program, asked about AGILE process and other software stuff that a sophomore wouldn't know, treated it like a regular SWE internship. I thought I did bad-ish, but I heard back a week later with good news. Then they scheduled a 30 minute technical interview with a software engineer manager. No coding questions, just technical concepts related to machine. They also asked if I had a follow-up questions from the behavioral interview. Answered them really well and related to their hobbies. Heard back a month later telling me I did not get the offer. It was definitely because of the behavioral.
How familiar are you with C programming?

I applied through a staffing agency. The process took 1 week.I interviewed at NVIDIA in 2/10/2024

I interviewed with the hiring manager who came 10 minutes late to a 30-minute HM screen. I got the impression that she didn't respect me or my time. She also made no effort to get to know me or what I could bring to the table. The interview questions she had for me contained little substance and didn't allow me to expand or pivot to my experience. Questions such as: What would your best friend describe you as? She finished the interview by saying she "was interviewing people with double my experience, but my biggest asset was that I was local to their HQ, so I could learn faster." WHAT? I'm sure she didn't mean to be condescending, but it was so insulting and patronizing, especially since I didn't get a chance to advocate for myself. I just sat there taken aback as she excused herself immediately afterwards. Why waste both of our time if you're just going to ask me garbage questions? How does that benefit anyone? Such a frustrating and disappointing interview.
What is one thing you expect of your team?

I applied online. The process took 4 days.I interviewed at NVIDIA (San Jose, CA) in 12/20/2023

Most of the interview rounds went very well, and I enjoyed talking to everyone I met...right up until the last person. He was obviously not engaged, barely paying attention, and responding to questions for clarifications with two to three word responses. The only reason I don't think he was doing the video call from his phone was camera orientation, but he was definitely walking while carrying whatever device he was using during 80% of the interview. No intro, no initial conversation, straight to the "test." Interviewer: "Write a function that's in the standard library of every single language" Me: That's definitely something I'd flag in a review, but okay. Do you want it quick and dirty, or do you want it efficient? Interview: DO IT RIGHT! (Yes, he actually shouted) Me: Wow.. okay.. Well, "right" is using the one in the standard library, but beyond that, there's a lot of minutiae surrounding that, because you have to account for A, B, C, D, E, F, etc.. How many of these cases should I be accounting for? Interviewer: It just needs to work. I pretty quickly threw something together, ignoring the aforementioned edge cases, and again asked "how many of the things I brought up earlier do I need to account for? Let's iterate from here." Apparently, that wasn't the approach this gentleman wanted, because things went from moderately uncomfortable to downright hostile. Maybe I'm used to working in collaborative environments (and I've been a team lead with hiring responsibilities for over 15 years) where its more important to figure out if you can work with someone and communicate about technical problems effectively vs "write a function that does X." If I had gotten an offer and that person was on my team, it would've been a hard pass. My time is too valuable to waste on stand-offish jerks.

The entire process spanned approximately four weeks. Throughout this period, I observed a significant degree of disorganization from both the recruiter and coordinator. Following a successful first-round interview with the hiring manager, during which we established a positive rapport (although this may not have been the case), I promptly made myself available for the subsequent week as the hiring manager expressed a keen interest in moving forward. Regrettably, there was a noticeable lack of responsiveness when I forwarded my availability to the recruiter and coordinator. It was only at the conclusion of that week that I received any form of communication. I was informed that the initial recruiter had been replaced during the process. Subsequently, I no longer had any interactions with a recruiter and was solely in contact with the coordinator. Unfortunately, none of the proposed times I had provided were deemed suitable. It took an entire week to receive a response based on the availability I had provided two weeks in advance. Despite being advised to seek answers from my recruiter, she remained unresponsive throughout the process. Overall, I found the process to be highly disorganized and unsatisfactory.
Explain OWASP top 10 and what it means

The interview process, lasting four months, included unexpected emphasis on deep learning, which was mentioned in the job description but not as a central component. It involved an Omniverse Home Project, a technical interview, two manager interviews, and an HR interview. Key issues I faced were the use of an outdated resume, overlooking my pertinent portfolio, HR's lack of clarity about the hiring manager, and vague feedback stating I wasn't the right fit for the team. They also did not contact my previous two direct managers for references. Furthermore, not considering my portfolio and judging my capabilities solely based on my resume placed me at an unfair disadvantage, misrepresenting my true skills and abilities. Overall, this extensive process resulted in considerable disappointment.

I applied online. The process took 3 months.I interviewed at NVIDIA (Yerevan, Yerevan) in 11/25/2023

I applied for the Senior Data Engineer position at the Yerevan Office on the 26th of July 2023 and got a response on the 21st of September, after 2 months (shocking). And the response was from the recruitment coordinator, saying let's have a technical interview on 4th October, (no HR, no screening, etc) The tech interview was quite good, I felt that I made a good impression. We mostly talked about Apache Spark and its internals, with some questions about distributed systems. The next day, another recruiter reached out to me and asked when I was ready to make a system design home assessment, and after confirming that I was okay - they sent me the task with a 2-week time limit. I did my best to complete the task, which was a quite good solution and sent it after 10 days. A couple of days later, I got a standard message from the recruiter coordinator, saying "Unfortunately, at this time, we decided to proceed our interview process with another candidate. It is a decision we didn't make easily because you are really a strong candidate with a wonderful personality." Mostly, my feedback is negative because of my pipe dream to work in a FANG-level company and because I've spent too much time dreaming that everything is going well during this interview process. Interestingly, the position is still open (end of November), and even it was reposted on Linkedin.

Which types of query optimization do I know in Spark, and how do they work internally? How to make a join with two big datasets, if the joining condition is not strict (expected to hear about product join and keep only relevant rows) Other in-depth questions about spark-streaming internals, and big data techs like kafka, zookeeper, etc.

Very disappointing process. Very unorganized and disrespectful. They dont know what they're looking for and assign random interviewers without having a chat internally. The recruiter never bothered to reply to my emails prior to the interview. Talked directly to the HM, which was a standard screening round. Finally got a conversation a day before the panel interview where I was provided some choppy info on what to expect in the next round. At the end, I asked -- "is this related to the role, because based on my chat with the HM, I didnt think this was needed?". -- they said, "not really.". Other interviews were find, pretty standard. I never got an email from the recruiter or even an automated email.

It started with a one-on-one session with the hiring manager where I got a clear understanding of the role and the company's expectations. Then a problem-solving / coding interview on HackerRank from a medium to difficult level of chellenges. After that, I went through a series of six interviews with diverse team members, covering topics relevant to the position. From Deep Learning algorithms, NLP, LLMs, ASR and TTS models development, MLOps, data engineering, product management and also some more problem solving and coding. Throughout the process, the team members were professional and kind, creating a positive interview environment. While the process may seem lengthy, for those seeking to join a cutting-edge team in the tech industry; I think that it is well worth the investment.
Elaborate a solution to solve the problem of information retrieval for very large docuemnts

I applied online. The process took 2 weeks.I interviewed at NVIDIA (Stuttgart) in 9/26/2023

I interviewed for a remote position in Germany. The recruiter first contacts you indicating that they're interested in setting up an interview with you. Before each interview round, you get a Google form where you can indicate up to 5 slots of your availability. The recruiter will then set up a meeting for each interview based on your availability. The recruiter and feedback process is fast and seamless. They also give you a gist of what each interview is going to be about in advance. Round 1: Usually with an engineering manager - general talk about your CV and a small coding exercise. This round went well for me, I was able to answer all questions and solve a coding challenge with a little help from the interviewer. Round 2: Technical interview with one/two developers. This round also contains a small coding challenge. In this round, I was able to answer all questions, but unfortunately I could not solve the coding challenge completely. There was no communication from the recruiter after the 2nd round. I only found out that my application is no longer in consideration from the status on the myworkdayjobs portal.
Generic questions on automotive software development topics: CAN, SOME/IP, ASR components.

I applied online. The process took 2 months.I interviewed at NVIDIA in 10/4/2023

The interview process spanned over two months and comprised four rounds: two initial screening rounds, a panel interview involving five interviewers, and a final interview with a senior manager. It was quite engaging as it delved into a wide range of topics, including questions related to my resume, computer architecture, operating systems, and embedded systems. Proficiency in C++ and a strong understanding of Object-Oriented Programming (OOP) were essential. The OOP segment of the interview was particularly in-depth, with a lot of intriguing questions. During the panel interview, each of the five interviewers focused on a specific topic. Overall, it was a comprehensive and stimulating interview process.

Q: Given a stack class implementation (LIFO) - there are 3 methods - push(), pop(), isempty(). Write a class using objects of given class to implement a FIFO. Q: Write a code for this condition, string - tell if it is valid. "{}" it is valid. "}{" not valid. Q: A computer system uses a two-level page table for address translation. Given that the system has a 32-bit virtual address (VA) space and a 32-bit physical address (PA) space, and it utilizes a 4 KB page size: a.How many bits in the VA are used for the page offset? b.If the remaining bits from the VA are split evenly between the two levels of the page table, how many bits are used to index into the first-level page directory and the second-level page table? c.Calculate the number of entries each first-level page directory can have and the number of entries each second-level page table can have. d.Given that each page table entry (PTE) is 4 bytes, determine the size (in bytes) of a second-level page table. Q: write a function to set a particular field of register to the desired value. (For example, set bit 3 - 10 of a word to the given value) Q: Object slicing and many OOPs related questions

I applied through other source. The process took 3 months.I interviewed at NVIDIA in 9/15/2023

I had a very negative experience with NVIDIA. I was told that 2 teams were interested in my resume and was offered the option to interview with both. A few days after interviewing with the first team I was told I was moving on to the offer stage, and they asked me whether I still wanted to interview with the other team, which I did (since I was interested in both teams). I asked if interviewing with the second team would impact my chances with the first team and I was told by the recruiter it wouldn't. Moving forward a few weeks, I went through the interview process with the second team, but didn't pass the on-site interview panel. When I asked for updates about the offer with the first team, I was then told that they wouldn't be giving me an offer after all. The recruiter was surprisingly unprofessional about it and very callous in their answers, despite the fact that I was stressed about it. The first time I realized something went wrong was when they just said: "Please move forward with your other offers the team has decided to take the role a different direction". I was really taken aback because a few days before I had been told that I was the top candidate for the position and that they were still interested in moving forward. When I asked for a reason, I was told that it was because I was interested in a hybrid role but they later decided (after interviewing me) that they preferred to have the position fully in office. So apparently they decided I wasn't a good fit, even without asking me if I was ok with a fully in-office role? I suspect this was a lie, because when I confirmed that I'd still be interested in an in-office position, then a few days later the story changed again. This whole ordeal put me in a difficult position, as I rejected other competing offers thinking I could rely on this one. In general, telling a candidate they are moving to the offer stage, but then actually rejecting them, is a very unprofessional move. I have been through many interview processes but this is the first time it happens to me. This recruiter communicated with me very badly and gave me a very negative view of the company.
A mix of relatively standard coding interviews and more high-level interviews about computer vision/image processing

I had a very negative experience with NVIDIA. I was told that 2 teams were interested in my resume and was offered the option to interview with both. A few days after interviewing with the first team I was told I was moving on to the offer stage, and they asked me whether I still wanted to interview with the other team, which I did (since I was interested in both teams). I asked if interviewing with the second team would impact my chances with the first team and I was told by the recruiter it wouldn't. Moving forward a few weeks, I went through the interview process with the second team, but didn't pass the on-site interview panel. When I asked for updates about the offer with the first team, I was then told that they wouldn't be giving me an offer after all. The recruiter was surprisingly unprofessional about it and very callous in their answers, despite the fact that I was stressed about it. The first time I realized something went wrong was when they just said: "Please move forward with your other offers the team has decided to take the role a different direction". I was really taken aback because a few days before I had been told that I was the top candidate for the position and that they were still interested in moving forward. When I asked for a reason, I was told that it was because I was interested in a hybrid role but they later decided (after interviewing me) that they preferred to have the position fully in office. So apparently they decided I wasn't a good fit, even without asking me if I was ok with a fully in-office role? I suspect this was a lie, because when I confirmed that I'd still be interested in an in-office position, then a few days later the story changed again. This whole ordeal put me in a difficult position, as I rejected other competing offers thinking I could rely on this one. In general, telling a candidate they are moving to the offer stage, but then actually rejecting them, is a very unprofessional move. I have been through many interview processes but this is the first time it happens to me. This recruiter communicated with me very badly and gave me a very negative view of the company.

Seems like an AI selection process where candidates are brought up to the hiring manager. Once selected, the HR set up a direct call with the hiring manager for 15 mins! 15 mins is not enough by any means for a meaningful interview. My call took over 30 mins and in the end despite the plethora of career progress and achievements shared, the hiring manager asked for a list of marketing examples to be shared within 3 business days for review. This is good for early career candidates but not for seasoned coming for a larger successful organization and ones who have a proven track record. In the end the response was more along the lines that I was over qualified, which was nothing but a waste of time for me.
list of marketing articles to stand out

1st round was with the Hiring Manager and a Senior DS on the team. 1 hour-long pleasant conversation about my work experience and passion for the role. 2nd round was a panel style where I met 4 people across 3 different interviews. This was where it got funny where two of the interviewers had no idea which role I was interviewing for. While most of them were nice and friendly, one of them, being a higher up, repeatedly asked me on Why Nvidia for 4-5 times to the extent of being unreasonable. She admitted that she joined the Teams call without knowing what role/team I was interviewing for and proceeded to treat me as a Solution Architect candidate. Her overall demeanor was condescending. To top it all off, the recruiter ghosted me for 2 weeks then finally replied that I should reach out again if I don't hear back from her, and after 3 weeks when I had called her, she responded the team had moved on with other candidates. Extremely unprofessional and disorganized behavior all around. They have 0 idea on how to handle the crazy $$$ coming in and treat their candidates and employees like their little primary school kids.
0 technical questions. Strictly behavioral and a litmus test for whether the Director of Solution Architect likes you and thinks you're docile enough.

I interviewed for one of the Autonomous Vehicle divisions. Standard tech interview process. - Phone Screen with Recruiter - Tech Screen Domain Experience. - Tech Screen Coding - Day long virtual interview. 5 interviews with a mix between domain experience and coding. A couple of followup conversations to discuss role and interview. Overall had a negative experience which ultimately lead me to declining the offer. - Recruiter scoffed at my compensation request, and really tried to downplay my experience/skill level to justify a lower offer. Other company I eventually accepted didn't even blink. Was ~80K difference. - Was dismissive of my wishes to push my start date by 3 weeks. Wanted me to quit my previous role and start the next week.
- Rigid body transforms - Pathfinding - Matrix multiplication

Three interviewers, one after another, conducted the interview process. Overall, I felt extremely disrespected by the interviewers, particularly one of them who held the highest position. For instance, during the interview, I was asked about who the SA is for the job. I told the interviewer that I didn't find any mention of SA in the job description. However, he expressed disbelief and questioned my familiarity with the job description, despite the fact that SA was indeed not mentioned in it. Furthermore, it felt quite belittling when an interviewer lacking a computer science background or software development experience doubted my programming abilities without even conducting an online coding test. As a Ph.D. in computer science, it was disheartening to be questioned in such a manner. Additionally, the interviewer did not assess my English abilities but instead questioned my proficiency in the language. In minor matters, I was asked to present some slides regarding my recent work, even though HR did not inform me about it in advance.
Q: Please introduce any machine learning model in a mathematical way.

Contacted via multiple internal recruiters. Went back and forth a few times to align schedules. Interview call was to be done remotely via Teams. First scheduled time was set approximately 2 weeks in advance, then the interview was cancelled a few hours before it was to be held. Given the call was via Teams, it normally wouldn't have been an issue, but I had already rearranged my childcare schedule and pushed interviews with other employers to accommodate. Rescheduled for a second time, interviewer was a delegate of the hiring manager, was over 10min late, and not given the appropriate background information. The delegate did allow the interview to extend beyond the scheduled time to makeup for the delay. Received feedback three days later that they would be pursuing other candidates. I did appreciate the prompt conclusion.

Q: How do you know if the product is 'well designed'? Q: Pick a product - how would you make it better and what are the implications of doing that? Q: Give an example of a time when you had to balance multiple priorities, how did you prioritize? Q: How do you handle a situation when you have to say 'no' to a request?

(1) After initial discussions with the recruiter, the first interview is a screening interview with a team member. (2) Second is another screening interview with the Hiring Manager. (3) The third and final step is a full-day of back-to-back interviews with team members from engineers to PMs to VPs. Like many employers, the company likes to say they have a great working environment and that they're looking for people who think out of the box. Discussions with interviewers and personal internal contacts tell me neither are true. They want typical get-in-line and stay-in-your-box employees who will work 12-14 hours per day, including weekends. The hiring manager does not have final word on providing an offer. Higher-level managers can overrule and deny an offer to anyone they do not like or did not like an answer from. Overall, the interview process and questions were easy and not out of the ordinary.
Is title important to you?

I had a mixed experience with the interviewers. Some were extremely warm and receptive, and engaged with me throughout the interview and offered continuous feedback, whereas others engaged very little and seemed to be working on other things during the interview. I received questions that were significantly longer than can be fully completed during the time allotted. I repeated the question after the interview for practice purposes and even knowing exactly what to do I was only able to finish about 30% of some of the exercises. I had to code nearly the entire time allotted. The role primarily mentioned Javascript and frontend development, and I was only asked frontend questions., not any of the more FAANG style algorithm questions tagged with NVIDIA on leetcode. I rated my overall experience negatively because all interviewers should be engaged, and if a question is significantly longer than what a candidate can expect to complete, it is a good practice to state this upfront.
Vanilla Javascript and React questions using online IDEs

applied via LinkedIN, had first screening interview with internal recruiter and I've been put forward for interview with Hiring manager. They sounded they are not in the same team, as the recruiter wished me good luck several times as if it was an agency with no power... Interview with hiring manager from USA was very high level, despite positive feedback around skills and experience they didn't want to progress and they haven't provided any feedback. Also, this was the first time I haven't been informed of the salary package during a recruiting process, I have found this very odd, as it is obviously one of the first factors to determine interest in a role. I had the feeling they were very disorganised and a bit desperate to fill the role with someone, also recruiter provided a very different job description compared to the description provided by the hiring manager, overall I was expecting Nvidia to be a lot more professional and organised ,I guess that the organic growth they had in the past few years, and an impact on efficiency, also in the hiring space. Also don't forget it is a US company, so work ethic and values are very different from what we consider in Europe/UK.
Q: how do yo manage people and support them in their career?

I applied online. I interviewed at NVIDIA (San Francisco, CA) in 9/27/2022

The Senior Manager's in IT were some of the most arrogant & cocky individuals I've ever interacted with, in a professional setting. I get the feeling that Nvidia has a ton of politics and arrogant individuals. I'd avoid at all costs. I was really close to dropping out of the interview process. As it took them a super long time to get back to me, even after I passed the interviews. I had 6 rounds of interviews, between coding and manager based interviews. One female manager was actively slacking and emailing people WHILE interviewing me. She paid me zero attention. I could see her looking back between different screens and typing, as she was conducting the interview. It showed a complete lack or respect, and was insanely unprofessional. This is when I decided to leave the interview process. You should seriously consider just interviewing here to leverage their offer, against your current employer or against other offers. That's the only reason to interview here. I feel bad for people who have to work in this environment.

They asked easy JavaScript questions. The technical interviewer would try oddly hard to "trip you up", and ask if "You're 100% sure" with your answer, before rendering your code. After saying, "Yes, I'm Positive" a few times (and being right), he kept on doing it. So they try to inject fear into the interview process, which is lame. I've completed several technical interviews, even with FANG companies, over the past decade, and the technical interview with Nvidia was the most obnoxious experience from all of them. Get better at interviewing people.

I applied online. The process took 2 months.I interviewed at NVIDIA in 11/11/2022

The process is incredibly long. From time of application to the end took 2.5 months. For such an established company to take this much time and internal resources to get a candidate vetted is highly unusual. The interview process is also very weird. At the beginning of each interview, they asked me -- the candidate -- how many prior interviews I've had with them. Which tells me that each interview is independent (not necessarily a bad thing), but it also shows how little internal transparency they have to incoming candidates. Lastly, after the hiring team being very quick to respond during the process, when it came time to give or decline an offer I ended up getting hardly any responses and felt like I had to keep following up to continue the process. That being said, there are a lot of smart engineers working there, and I did enjoy the interviews. They asked good questions and were pleasant to talk to.
Standard questions like: - Reverse bits in a 32bit unsigned integer - Swap two bits in an unsigned integer - Implement a scheduler in an embedded RTOS - Lots of bit manipulation and XOR tricks

I had four interviews total, including screening, coding, system design interviews, and a conversation with a staff engineer. The interviewing process was smooth and pretty much straightforward. Yet, after sharing a reference declaration form, I was ghosted. Later attempts to reach the HR manager gave me little to no clarity regarding the status of the application. Every answer claimed the application "is in progress." It seems they're stockpiling candidates unless they find the suitable one, and then they don't even care about canceling the unfit applications.
A few low-level C questions followed by an application design exercise. Describe the most challenging bug you've faced in your career.

I interviewed at NVIDIA in 5/19/2022

The interview process was an absolute train wreck. After speaking with the hiring manager, I came to find out that the role description did not match the role they were trying to fill. This affected my ability to prepare for the interviews and to even determine if I was a good fit at all. I got to the final round after having completed 7 “virtual onsite” interviews, each 45 minutes long. None of the interviewers had came prepared with relevant questions. In one instance, I was even asked to explain the role I was applying for because the interviewer admitted to not have taken the time to review that information beforehand. I am not sure how the panel members were selected to conduct the interviews, but it was clear that there was significant miscommunication amongst those involved in this process - and frankly, a lack of care to even prepare at all. In all honesty, I am quite disappointed in my interview experience at NVIDIA. It is clear that although everyone is incredibly hard working and committed to their work, it comes at a great cost. I selected “No” under the question of getting an offer. The reality is that I never got a response, even after completing the final round of interviews. I followed up with emails but never heard back. It is quite a shame - I had really high hopes of wanting to love NVIDIA as much as its employees apparently do.
What is your least favorite part of your job?

I had an initial call then was asked to come for a technical interview. After that I was asked to come for an HR interview. The interviewers were late at least 10 minutes as they haven't arrived to the office yet even though it was during working hours. After the official interview time was over, they asked if I could stay longer to continue with their questions. I had an appointment so I couldn't stay. They were more interested in ticking the boxes rather than giving a feel of the company culture. After that they sent an automated mail (I'm assuming to all candidates) saying the vacancy was put on hold. Massive waste of my time and worst impression any employer can give really. I will never apply for anything again in Nvidia due to my bad HR experience.

Very disorganized and unprofessional recruiter who would schedule an interview and then cancel it last minute, and then schedule another two weeks later without providing transparency. I thought the negative reviews on here would not apply to me, but they turned out to be accurate depictions of how NVIDIA interviews. I did 10 long interviews over eight weeks plus a take home assignment before receiving no offer or anything for my time. Despite interviewing top talent, they have no respect for interviewees’ time and play interviewees, unlike any FAANG company. It’s not a serious hiring process and the recruiters are very sloppy. I really regret wasting my time and should have declined after the first red flag, but I did the interview because I was invited multiple times by the recruiter to interview for this position.

Coding questions. I also interviewed with the entire team one at a time, and some asked questions that were very unrelated to the position and just improvised. All went very well anyways, which is why I had to do 10 of them. They are looking for perfection.

After almost 10 weeks I withdrew my application. At that point I had had three technical interviews. I accepted an offer from another company. They took weeks after one interview to schedule the next. My application was bounced between at least four HR representatives. The interview process was not transparent, I did not know how many interviews I was to have nor what they would entail. There was one very inappropriate and unfortunate experience. I have a disability and requested accommodations during the interview process. I filled out accommodation paperwork online and was told my accommodation requests would be met. I showed up for my second technical interview and the interviewer described the plan for the hour, which directly conflicted with the accommodations I needed. I informed him there must have been some communication error between him and HR because I have a disability and the interview he had planned did not meet my accommodations. I suggested we reschedule after getting it sorted out with HR. The interviewer repeated accused me of being unprepared for the interview. Having a disability does not mean unpreparedness. I found that implication very insulting. I stayed in the interview process following that experience because of nvidia’s reputation and HR’s insistence that they would adhere to my accommodations moving forward. After that, it took three weeks to schedule my next interview. A week and a half after that interview I asked if they had feedback. They informed me it would be another week until they had feedback for me. In that time I accepted an offer from another company.
Deep learning algorithm implementation specifics: dropout, batch norm, Adam, cross entropy, sigmoid, regression, normalization

I applied through other source. The process took 1 week.I interviewed at NVIDIA (Santa Clara, CA) in 4/11/2022

One interview screening with program managers, two interviews with teammates, and one with the hiring manager, 30 min each. I was reached out via LinkedIn. My interview process was speeded up because I was in the final rounds with another company. My first interview with the program managers was the best interview I had ever had, and it made me want to work there. Then the rest of the interviews was a neutral experience. The recruiter coordinator was fast. I was able to have all my interviews scheduled within a week. I was impressed with all my interactions except for the recruiter. He was so unprofessional and that made me not want to work there even if I was given the offer. He didn't answer my emails until I followed up that I had received another offer. During our phone call, he was talking over me, couldn't give me direct answers to my questions, cutting me off, told me to go ask for an extension with my other offer, and then started giving me unsolicited career advice. I am sure he had good intentions, but he needs additional training. TLDR: Great experience with interviewers/recruiter coordinator, worst experience with recruiter
Questions about prioritization skills, planning, details, organizing, experience with event planning, juggling ambiguity, and how would I make great experiences for interns/new folks.

I was referred by an employee, the process is two tech interviews and then an HR interview. I didn't pass the first one. The interview took place in Teams. Almost two hours, with a little break in the middle. There were two interviewers, they were nice. First I had to tell about myself, then they asked me some questions regarding my cv and the little experience that I have, then a couple of theoretical questions that are related to the role, most were about networks and things I studied in my degree (Software Engineering), then two simple code questions. They didn't give me choice in which language to solve the code, they gave one question in Python and another one in java. The role was for the DOCA team.

First Question: Python question: Find all unique elements listLang = [CPP, PYTHON, JAVA, JAVA, CPP] Second Question: Public int foo(List<Integer> nums){ Int x = -1; Int y = -1; For(Integer num : nums){ If(x < num){ Y = x; X = num; } Return y; { What is the code supposed to do? What is the problem? How can you fix it? (They said they weren't supposed to ask this question, they were curious.

I applied online. The process took 8 weeks.I interviewed at NVIDIA (Santa Clara, CA) in 5/19/2022

Confusing. There was no structure. I applied and was asked to interview for several DevOps engineer positions at NVIDIA, none of which were straightforward or concise. Summary: Typically 4 rounds, Interview with director, manager, then team lead, followed by coding leet code style questions. This may be drastically different for you, however. I had another DevOps role in NVIDIA and I had leetcode questions right off the bat. Asked the recruiter for assistance and they provided no insight on who I would be interviewing or how technical the interview was going to be. The leetcode at the end was a huge surprise and in DevOps typically leetcode is rare because of the nature of the work we do. I was shocked to be asked some medium questions and one hard (4 total) during the FINAL round. This confused me and caught me off guard because most companies do leetcode first in the process.They really have no clue how to interview software candidates for DevOps and it clearly shows. Overall, I would not recommend this as the process took upwards of 2 months for one position, wasting time waiting a week or more for the recruiter to "hear back from the team" to move on to the next step. The time I wasted interviewing and preparing was immense and my disappointment in how the process was handled makes me incredibly weary considering joining the company again.
What is your favorite programming language?

I had 3 interviews. Most of them starts with asking you what are you doing in your current job. Then technical questions. I must say that when they ask about a current task you had, they are trying to get to a point of a low level, most of the time going out of the context of your task, which was pretty exhausting, because you try to explain something you've done, and they go to a place they feel comfortable. You can say you wrote a complete high level module, but they keep asking something like, "oh your input was x, and you got it on can , how does that work?" Even though it is not even related to what you explain. I also must say that at least half of their questions are hard to understand, they open a web thing with questions to write code, and they don't explain exactly the task. My impression was not so good.
Given a 2D matrix, on every "0" appearance cell, you need to zero all the cells in the same column/row.

I was contacted through email by a Recruiting Coordinator after submitting my resume through the career portal. First round was a phone screen to go through my resume, why I was interested in the role and what qualifications I had that aligned with the position. Recruiting Coordinator worked me with to arrange the next two rounds, which were all video due to no on-site interviews. Every member was nice, engaging and clearly loves their job. Most of them have been there for years, which is not common in tech. Follow up was great and was guided from start to finish. They allowed me to ask honest questions and I could tell their responses were genuine.
How do you manage your time?

Two phone screenings and 5 onsite interviews. All interviews are virtual through Microsoft Teams. The hiring manager will interview you first with general questions about your experience. The second call is a coding challenge. The onsite interview includes coding challenges like leetcode as well as design questions. Challenges are getting more difficult as the stages progress. Make sure you are vocal and share your thought process. It counts more than you think.
Modern C++, make sure you know smart pointers, inheritance, virtual functions, data structures

Unfortunately, this experience completely changed my opinion of the company.

I applied through referral of a friend. There was a telephonic screening interview followed by 5 virtual video interviews. The whole process took 4 weeks. I got the reply after 1 week of the telephonic interview and 2 weeks after the virtual interviews.

Verify the Round Robin arbiter with priorities. Find nth maximum number in an array They gave various designs and asked me how would you verify it. Write the code for the scoreboard. What kind of challenges you will face while verifying the design? What is polymorphism in SV? Where do you use it? 2 x 2 router verification. In-order and out-of-order. They asked me to write the constraints for some cases for eg write followed by read on the same address. It looks like a important part of their interview process.

I applied online. I interviewed at NVIDIA (Santa Clara, CA) in Nov 21, 2021

"Wannabe Big Tech" Pros - The brand name Cons I am writing this review from a combination of few different interview experiences at Nvidia (both mine and others that I know). Nvidia wants to be considered in the Big Tech league, hence tries to behave like them (talking, interviews etc). However once you go through the interview loop and talk to peers working at Nvidia you realize, there is a lot of "empty vessel" there. For people interested in autonomous driving, you are better off interviewing at one of the better companies like Cruise, Waymo etc. Specific to the interview - 1) Unstructured interviews. Fun fact - I was asked questions on the same topic in all of "8" rounds. Shows lack of preparation and experience in interviewing candidates. 2) Please learn how to interview senior engineers. You shouldn't be assigning junior engineers, ask in the box questions and expect memorized answers. 3) Lack of robust vision in autonomous driving. Highly demotivating managers (are they really managers ?)

Nvidia wants to be considered in the Big Tech league, hence tries to behave like them (talking, interviews etc). However once you go through the interview loop and talk to peers working at Nvidia you realize, there is a lot of "empty vessel" there. For people interested in autonomous driving, you are better off interviewing at one of the better companies like Cruise, Waymo etc. Specific to the interview - 1) Unstructured interviews. Fun fact - I was asked questions on the same topic in all of "8" rounds. Shows lack of preparation and experience in interviewing candidates. 2) Please learn how to interview senior engineers. You shouldn't be assigning junior engineers, ask in the box questions and expect memorized answers. 3) Lack of robust vision in autonomous driving. Highly demotivating managers (are they really managers ?)

It was with two of the team members, one is the team leader. took 2 hours. First told about the role, technologies and what I will need to do amoung the team. Then ask about me, personal projects, courses, relevant role knowlege. Finaly tecnical questions.

1. logical question- given a 2000 digits number, wich starts with the digit 3, and every two next-to-each-other digits (that are together a decimal number), neads to divide in 17 or 23, what will be the last digit of this numer. 2. write an allocate and free function for a user, while you have 32 rows in the memory to allocate(each allocation gives one avialable row), and 32 bit personal memory to use. 2.1 you have 64 rows in the memory to allocate, and still 32 bit personal memory to use.

I applied through an employee referral. The process took 2 weeks.I interviewed at NVIDIA in Oct 6, 2022

Standard SWE interview process, but all questions were linear algebra. Reading online, I actually way overshot, memorizing some algorithms out of Golub Matrix Computations. Between this and because my linear algebra education was more theoretical/ upper and grad level math oriented, I had to spend time on the product with transpose and less on upper triangular times upper triangular.

Implement matrix multiplication (assume square), then refactor for A * A^T (assume square), then refactor for upper triangular (assume square), and then back to generic O(n^3) matrix multiplication, how could this be parallelized?

At the end, I didn't pass. Very low quality interviewer and very negative feelings after.
"Minimum number of refueling stops" on leetcode
